writing_prompt: In a quiet chamber bathed in golden light, Annatar weaves jewels into Celebrimbor's hair, each gem a whispered promise, each touch a fleeting moment of devotion. But beneath the tenderness lies a shadow—what truths remain unspoken between the Maia and the elf?
story:
The sun was nearing its zenith, and the light filtered through the tall windows of their private chamber in soft, golden beams. It cast an ethereal glow upon the two figures within, making the room seem suspended between reality and some otherworldly realm.
The light played upon the fine lines and contours of Celebrimbor’s face, making him look almost sublime, as though he were carved from light itself. Annatar sat perched in Celebrimbor’s lap, his fingers deftly weaving delicate jewels into the elf’s dark hair - it was as if he were offering a prayer to some higher power, and in a way, he was. Each gem, whether sapphire, diamond, or ruby, caught the light, adding a constellation of glittering stars to the already striking midnight of Celebrimbor’s locks.
They were alone in the quiet room, the only sounds being the soft murmur of the wind outside and the occasional clink of metal as Annatar reached for another jewel from the small velvet box beside him. There was no rush, no pressure. Just the slow, deliberate act of adorning Celebrimbor, of turning his beloved into a vision that could have rivaled the splendor of the Valar themselves.
Today, the rings and their grim purpose were far from Annatar's mind. There were no dark thoughts, no heavy burdens weighing down his heart. There was only this moment, where the world beyond ceased to exist and it was just them - Annatar and his beloved, enshrined in their own sanctuary of light and affection.
Celebrimbor, for his part, seemed content to indulge Annatar’s whims. He sat still, his back against the plush cushions on the wide settee, his arms loosely wrapped around Annatar's waist, as the Maia adorned his dark hair with jewels.
To an onlooker, it would have seemed like a scene from a dream - an image of devotion and love, of absolute adoration. And, for Annatar, it very much was.
Annatar leaned in, pressing a feather-light kiss to Celebrimbor’s temple as he secured a small, delicate sapphire above his ear. “Perfect,” he whispered, his voice almost reverent. “You look divine. Like a star in the heavens.”
Celebrimbor chuckled softly, his head tilting slightly as he glanced at Annatar with a fond, amused smile. “You have a flair for exaggeration, my love,” he said, though there was no denying the warmth in his gaze, the way he leaned into Annatar’s touch. “It’s just a few jewels.”
Annatar’s eyes sparkled with something almost feral, his grin widening as he pressed a gentle kiss to the corner of Celebrimbor’s lips. “Nothing is ever ‘just’ anything when it comes to you, Tyelpe,” he said, his voice carrying a hint of playfulness, but underneath it lay something deeper, something almost solemn. “You don’t see yourself the way I do.”
He leaned back slightly, his eyes roving over Celebrimbor’s face, the curve of his lips, the sharp line of his jaw, the eyes that had fallen closed in contentment, the elegance that seemed to radiate from him in effortless waves. Annatar felt something fierce and tender rise in his chest, a feeling that was almost too much to contain, too big for even him to grasp fully.
“I sometimes think,” he continued softly, his fingers now tracing the delicate shell of Celebrimbor’s ear, where he had placed a small, intricate cuff adorned with moonstones, “that you could have been one of the Ainur. A Valar, even.” There was a wistful note in his voice, a yearning for a reality that could not be.
Celebrimbor opened his eyes, glancing at Annatar with a soft smile. “A Valar?” he repeated, amusement lacing his tone. “I am far from that, I assure you.”
Annatar shook his head, his fingers gently twining another jewel into Celebrimbor’s hair. “No, you would have been perfect. You are perfect. Kind, wise, strong - everything a good Valar should be.”
Celebrimbor chuckled softly, the sound vibrating through Annatar’s chest. “You speak as if you’ve forgotten the many faults I have.”
“Faults?” Annatar echoed, his voice filled with mock disbelief. “What faults, Tyelpe? If you have any, they are but the tiniest blemishes on a diamond, insignificant against your brilliance.”
Celebrimbor raised an eyebrow, clearly amused by Annatar’s words, but he allowed the Maia his whimsy. It was rare for Annatar to indulge in such fanciful thoughts, to be so open with his affection, and he didn’t want to break the spell.
“You would have made a fine ruler of Maiar, my lord,” Annatar continued, his voice soft, almost wistful.
The elf let out a soft sigh, his eyes closing again as he savored the warmth in Annatar’s words, the sheer adoration that shone in his gaze. He felt the weight of the jewels in his hair, each one a symbol of Annatar’s love, of his desire to adorn and protect. “And what would you do then, my dear? If I were a Valar?”
Annatar pressed his forehead against Celebrimbor’s, his breath mingling with the elf’s, his heart thundering in his chest. “If you were a Valar, if I could make you one, I would serve you as your most loyal Maia. I would follow you without question, without hesitation. There would be no desire for anything more than to be by your side.”
There was something almost sad in his tone, a longing that Celebrimbor couldn’t quite place. He opened his eyes and reached up, his hand gently cupping Annatar’s cheek, forcing him to meet his gaze. “You would?” he asked, his voice tender.
“Yes,” Annatar whispered, his eyes dark and serious. “I would worship you like the very sun and stars. I would be yours, completely, without lies, without hesitation. You would never need to doubt my loyalty.”
Celebrimbor blinked, taken aback by the intensity in Annatar’s eyes, by the raw sincerity in his words. He raised another hand, cupping Annatar’s cheek, his thumb brushing over the Maia’s cheekbone with a gentleness that seemed almost out of place in such a powerful hand. “You speak as though I am some ancient deity, Annatar, when I am but an elf. No more than that.”
Annatar’s heart ached at the simplicity of those words. “If the world were fair, you would be a Valar, and I would serve only you, as I do now.” He placed another jewel, a diamond this time, near the crown of Celebrimbor’s head, his fingers brushing against the silky strands with almost painful tenderness.
Celebrimbor chuckled softly, one hand sliding down to rest against Annatar’s chest, feeling the steady beat of his heart beneath his fingertips. “But would you not get jealous, my love? If other Maiar were to serve me as well?”
Annatar froze for a moment, his fingers stilling as he considered the thought, a brief flash of possessiveness crossing his mind. “I would be, I suppose,” he admitted, leaning in to press a kiss to Celebrimbor’s lips, soft and sweet. “But as long as I was the one to adorn you like this, to worship you as I do now, I think I could bear it.”
Celebrimbor’s hand moved to cup the back of Annatar’s neck, deepening the kiss for a moment before they pulled away, foreheads resting together. “You say the most beautiful things,” he whispered, his eyes half-closed as he took in the Maia’s words, the sincerity in his gaze.
“It is easy, when I have you to inspire me,” Annatar replied, his fingers resuming their work. He added another jewel, and then another, each one placed with care, each one a declaration of his devotion. “You have no idea how often I wish things were different. That you were… more?”
“Is being an elf not enough for you?”Celebrimbor asked, his eyebrows raising slightly, a hint of amusement in his eyes.
Annatar’s gaze softened, his hand coming up to caress Celebrimbor’s cheek. “You misunderstand me, love. You are more than enough. It’s that the world doesn’t deserve you as you are. If I could, I would elevate you to the heavens. You would be more than…say
Melkor
ever was, in his prime. Beautiful, powerful, kind and just - everything he wasn’t.”
His voice dropped to a whisper, and he closed his eyes, as though the thought itself was too beautiful, too painful to bear. “If only… things were different.”
Celebrimbor was silent for a long moment, his eyes searching Annatar’s face, his own heart aching at the unspoken sorrow in the Maia’s voice. He knew there were things Annatar would not - could not - say, secrets he kept close to his chest, burdens he bore alone. But in this moment, Celebrimbor felt the weight of something unnameable between them, a shadow that lurked just beyond the reach of the sunlight.
He tilted Annatar’s chin up, forcing the Maia to meet his gaze. “We cannot change what is, Annatar,” he said gently, his voice steady and sure.
Annatar swallowed hard, his eyes shimmering with a depth of emotion that seemed almost too vast for his form to contain. He nodded, unable to speak, his throat tight, as he placed the last jewel in Celebrimbor’s hair - a large, radiant star sapphire that sat in the center above his forehead, catching the light and refracting it in a dazzling array of colors. Annatar sat back, his eyes drinking in the sight of Celebrimbor, now adorned like some celestial being, a vision of light and dark.
“You’re beautiful,” he breathed, his hand trembling slightly as he reached out to cup Celebrimbor’s face, his thumb brushing gently over the curve of his cheek. “My beautiful, perfect Tyelpe.”
For a moment, Celebrimbor saw the barest flicker of something in Annatar’s eyes - a vulnerability, a longing so deep and raw that it took his breath away. He leaned forward, his hands sliding around Annatar’s waist, pulling him close. “And I am yours,” he whispered, his lips brushing against the Maia’s. “Whether I am elf, Valar, or something in between. I am yours.”
Annatar’s breath hitched, his eyes closing as he leaned into Celebrimbor’s embrace, his arms wrapping around him tightly. “If only that were enough,” he murmured, the words barely audible, lost in the rustle of fabric.
Annatar closed his eyes, savoring the warmth, the gentleness. He wished, with every fiber of his being, that it could be enough. That he could be content with this, with just the two of them, without the weight of his plans and ambitions. But he knew it was a fleeting wish, a dream that could never last.
But for now, it was. For now, he could let himself believe in this, in the warmth of Celebrimbor’s arms, in the sweetness of his kiss. For this moment, he allowed himself to believe in a future that could never be, in a reality where he could stay by Celebrimbor’s side without fear, without deceit.
He would let himself imagine that they were more than what they were - two beings caught in a web of fate and deceit. He would pretend that they were just lovers, lost in a moment of peace and intimacy, without the shadow of what was to come hanging over them.
For this one afternoon, he was content to be here, in Celebrimbor’s lap, placing stars in his hair and pretending that they could be happy. Even if it was all a lie, he would hold onto it for as long as he could.
And maybe, just maybe, in that small, hidden part of his heart, he could believe that it wasn’t entirely a lie. That there was some truth to the love he felt, to the devotion that shone in his eyes as he gazed at Celebrimbor.
He leaned in, pressing a kiss to Celebrimbor’s forehead, just below the radiant sapphire, his lips lingering there. “I love you,” he whispered, the words a vow, a promise that he couldn’t keep but wanted to more than anything. “More than you will ever know.”
He could pretend, for just another moment, that there was no shadow on the horizon, that they could stay like this forever, wrapped in each other’s light - that for this one, brief moment, everything was perfect.

writing_prompt: Annatar, the master of deception, finds himself tangled in a life he never expected—waking up each morning in the arms of Celebrimbor, the elf he’s come to love. How long can he balance the warmth of this newfound peace with the shadow of his true intentions?
story:
The morning sun filtered softly through the windows of their shared chambers, casting a gentle golden glow over the room. The air was warm, the bedding luxurious, and Annatar was nestled comfortably beneath it, wrapped in the arms of his husband. He could feel Celebrimbor stirring beside him, and as much as he wanted to remain in the pleasant half-dream that held him, the warmth of the waking world was tugging at him, insisting he acknowledge the day.
Here, in Eregion, mornings were far kinder than they had ever been before. There were no harsh commands from a mad Lord, no looming shadows or endless hours of grueling labor. No oppressive darkness, and the silence was neither filled with dread nor foreboding.
Here, the mornings were filled with light, warmth, and the soft rustling of leaves outside their window. Here, there was Celebrimbor - gentle, patient, and steadfast. The thought alone made Annatar sigh contentedly as he felt Celebrimbor shift beside him.
A gentle pressure against his cheek made him stir at last, his lips curving into a small smile even before he opened his eyes. Another kiss, then another, soft as the touch of a breeze. Annatar remained still, letting the sensation wash over him.
He let out a quiet hum of pleasure as another kiss landed, this time on his cheek, and another, traveling down toward his jaw. It was a ritual Celebrimbor often indulged in when he thought Annatar was still asleep, lavishing him with affection as if he couldn’t help himself.
It was a far cry from the mornings Mairon had known, and the contrast only deepened the sense of comfort Annatar felt. In Angband, mornings had been cruel. Cold reminders of the endless demands of his lord, the relentless pursuit of power, and the ever-present danger of what failure might bring.
Annatar allowed himself a moment to simply breathe, to take in the peace of this morning. In Angband, there had been no such luxuries - no soft beds, no quiet mornings with a lover beside him. Morgoth had demanded obedience, demanded perfection, and Mairon had given it, if only to survive. He had crafted, schemed, and built empires - only for it all crumble in the end.
But Celebrimbor didn’t need to know any of that. He didn’t need to know the depths of Annatar’s past, or the darkness that lingered in his heart. He only needed to know that Annatar was here, in this moment, thoroughly enjoying every bit of attention he lavished upon him.
Annatar shifted slightly, cracking his eyes open to catch a glimpse of his husband’s face - so full of affection, so content in this peaceful moment. It was an image he wanted to savor. He let his eye close again, burying himself deeper into the blankets and into Celebrimbor's embrace.
"Are you still asleep, or are you simply enjoying being spoiled?" Celebrimbor's voice was soft, teasing, as yet another kiss brushed against Annatar's skin, this time at the corner of his mouth.
Annatar let out a low chuckle, still not fully opening his eyes. "Do I need to choose?" he murmured, his voice a little rough with sleep, but undeniably pleased.
Celebrimbor laughed quietly, his hand moving to stroke Annatar’s hair in slow, gentle motions. "You’re spoiled enough as it is," he said affectionately. "But I suppose I’m to blame for that."
"You are," Annatar agreed, his lips curling into a smirk even as he kept his eyes closed. "But I won't complain. Mornings like these are infinitely preferable to what I once knew."
There was a pause, and Annatar regretted letting the comment slip. Celebrimbor's hand stilled in his hair, and Annatar could feel the slight tension that came with his husband's curiosity. But Annatar was quick, and before Celebrimbor could ask any questions, he tilted his head slightly, nuzzling into his touch.
"All you need to know, love," Annatar murmured, his voice low and tender, "is that I thoroughly enjoy waking up like this. With you."
The tension melted away almost instantly, and Celebrimbor’s hand resumed its gentle caress through Annatar's dark hair. "As you should," he replied, leaning down to press another kiss to his forehead. "One day, you’ll tell me what that comment meant."
"Perhaps," Annatar conceded, his smirk softening into a genuine smile as he allowed himself to relax fully again. "But not today. Today, I think I deserve a little more indulgence, don’t you too?"
Celebrimbor sighed, but it was full of fondness. "You’re incorrigible," he muttered, though his tone was nothing but affectionate.
Annatar hummed in agreement, shifting slightly to curl closer to Celebrimbor, feeling the warmth of his body against his own. He lifted a hand to trace the curve of Celebrimbor’s jaw, his touch as soft as the kisses he had received earlier.
"Do you ever tire of this?" Annatar asked, his voice a quiet murmur. "Waking up just to indulge me?"
Celebrimbor smiled, shaking his head. "Never," he said, without hesitation. "I think I enjoy it as much as you do."
Annatar let out a soft hum of amusement, his fingers threading through Celebrimbor’s dark hair. "I am a very lucky Maia," he said, his tone light but sincere. "To have such a devoted husband."
Celebrimbor’s smile softened, and he leaned in to kiss him again, this time on the lips, slow and gentle. "And I, a very lucky elf."
For a moment, Annatar’s heart twisted, a fleeting reminder of the lie that lingered beneath his skin - the lie he had crafted so carefully, the persona he had built to make Celebrimbor trust him. He pushed it aside, buried it deep. There was no need to think of such things now.
He kissed Celebrimbor back, his hand slipping to rest at the small of his back. "Then we might both be fortunate," Annatar whispered against his lips.
They stayed like that for a while longer, wrapped in the warmth of each other, the world outside forgotten. Annatar’s past was a distant memory, a shadow that hovered at the edges of his mind but did not touch the present. Here, in this bed, in Celebrimbor’s arms, he could pretend that this was all there was - that this peace, this love, was everything.
He knew it wouldn’t last forever. One day, his plans would come to fruition, and the peace would shatter. But for now, in the morning light, with the elf he had come to love so deeply, Annatar allowed himself the luxury of forgetting what the future held - the luxury of feeling something he hadn’t allowed himself to feel in a long time.
Contentment.

writing_prompt: In the quiet of Valinor, Celebrimbor dreams of Annatar—his betrayer, his beloved. The Valar attempt to guide him toward healing, but how do you let go of a love that was both your greatest joy and deepest ruin?
story:
Celebrimbor turned away from Nienna’s touch, curling into himself on the bed at last, as if he could shut out the weight of their sorrow. His mind, exhausted from endless cycles of grief and confusion, finally surrendered to sleep - deep and dreamless at first, mercifully void of the torment that usually awaited him.
But then, slowly, a golden light filled the room.
When he opened his eyes, a familiar warmth washed over him. His heart stirred, a flicker of recognition sparking in his chest.
Annatar.
He blinked, sitting up as he took in the sight before him. No one else was there - no Nienna, no Irmo, no Estë. Only him.
Only
Annatar.
His beloved, the one who had once filled his life with warmth, even if that warmth had ultimately burned him.
It was too good to be true, yet that was exactly how it had always been with Annatar. Too perfect, too radiant, too intoxicatingly beautiful. But here he was, standing by the bedside, his golden eyes shining with that same soft glow Celebrimbor had come to associate with love, with comfort, with devotion.
And for a brief, fleeting moment, Celebrimbor allowed himself to believe it was real. To believe that his Annatar had come back to him, that the torment of the past had somehow been washed away.
Annatar moved closer, his hand reaching out to cup Celebrimbor’s face, just as he had done so many times before. That familiar touch, that warmth… Celebrimbor’s heart clenched with longing.
But before he could speak, Annatar’s mouth opened, and the words that spilled from his lips were ice.
“Listen, Tyelpe,” he said, and the tone - it was
wrong
, cold and sharp, laced with a cruelty that sent a chill down Celebrimbor’s spine. Not the warmth of Annatar, but the venom of Sauron. “It was all a lie. Everything. You were never cherished. You were never loved. You were nothing but a tool. You were always just something to be used.”
Celebrimbor blinked, the words felt…
wrong.
Not just the words, but the way they were spoken. The tone, the phrasing - it was all wrong. Annatar, even at his most cruel, had never spoken to him like this. Even when he revealed his true nature, when the mask of the golden Maia fell away, he had never been this… detached.
Celebrimbor didn’t flinch. He didn’t recoil. Instead, a dry, humorless laugh escaped his lips, almost involuntary, as if some part of him had grown tired of this charade. He looked into Annatar’s eyes - those golden, familiar eyes - and now saw the cracks in the illusion.
Another humorless laugh escaped his lips before he could stop it. He shook his head slightly, feeling the weight of the dream fall away, like an illusion dissolving before his eyes.
“That‘s not him, Lord Irmo,”he murmured, barely loud enough for the Valar, who he knew must be watching from beyond the dream, to hear.
Annatar’s expression shifted, a flash of surprise flickering across his face. It was so vivid, so accurate to the way Annatar had looked at him in life, that it almost made Celebrimbor falter. But he pressed on.
He reached out, grabbing Annatar’s wrist with a gentleness that surprised even him. He pulled him closer, their faces now mere inches apart. The golden light flickered in Annatar’s eyes, but Celebrimbor’s gaze remained steady, unyielding.
“Listen, Annatar,” he said, his voice low, steady. “I love you. I’ve loved you from the very start. Even if most of it was lies, you can’t deny that some of it was real. I’ve seen you -
truly
seen you. Like you’ve seen me. I will never unsee you.”
The words hung between them, heavy with a bittersweet finality. And there was a flicker of something - something almost startled - in the Maia’s eyes. His expression faltered for a brief second, as if caught off guard by the words. The illusion held, but barely. And in that moment, Celebrimbor’s heart softened, even in the midst of the dream.
He pulled Annatar into an embrace, wrapping his arms around him and burying his face into the familiar warmth of his shoulder.
It was the closest thing to relief he had felt in what seemed like an eternity.
Even if this was a dream, even if it was a lie, it felt real enough. Real enough to bring some comfort, some fleeting sense of peace.
At last, the dream dissolved, and Celebrimbor woke again, blinking in the soft morning light of Valinor. He almost grumbled in irritation, the soft embrace of the dream slipping away as reality set in.
For a brief, fleeting moment, he felt the warmth of Annatar’s embrace linger around him like a ghost. He hadn’t wanted to wake, not from this. Not from
him
.
The light that had bathed the dream, the vivid sensation of Annatar’s hand on his face, had been so real - so painfully, beautifully real - that for a few precious moments, he had believed it. He sighed, closing his eyes again, trying to hold onto that feeling just a little longer.
The sound of hushed voices finally reached his ears. Undoubtedly, Nienna, Irmo, and Estë were gathered near him, speaking quietly amongst themselves. Their voices were low, almost inaudible, but Celebrimbor caught fragments of the conversation.
“…perhaps it was too much,” Nienna was saying, her voice filled with concern.
“I don’t know if it was the right choice,” Irmo was saying, his tone contemplative. “It may have brought him closer to the truth. Maybe it was progress…”
Estë’s face was calm, though her expression held a trace of pity as she responded, “The dream didn’t shatter him, but I fear it only reinforced what he already believes. Is it progress if he still clings to that which harms him?”
Celebrimbor couldn’t help but sigh. He shifted in the bed, sitting up slowly, and the movement caught the attention of the Valar. Nienna’s sad eyes turned to him, her expression softening, while Irmo and Estë regarded him with a mixture of concern and curiosity.
“How do you feel, Tyelpe?” Nienna asked, her voice as gentle as ever.
Celebrimbor ran a hand through his dark hair, the faintest traces of a smile on his lips - though it was more tired than anything else. “How do I feel?” he repeated, his voice dry, hollow. “I suppose that depends on what you were hoping for.”
Irmo stepped forward, his gaze serious yet patient. “We were hoping to guide you toward acceptance, Celebrimbor. To help you see the truth of what has happened, and to let go of what binds you.”
Celebrimbor snorted softly, shaking his head. “
Acceptance
?” he muttered under his breath, his voice laced with bitterness. “What exactly am I meant to accept? That I was a fool? That I trusted someone who played me from the start? That everything I believed in was a lie? I
know
the truth.”
He looked up then, meeting Irmo’s gaze head-on. “Lord Irmo, you induced that dream,” he continued, his voice hardening, “You tried to make Annatar cold, cruel. Tried to force me to see the darkness in him.”
Irmo nodded slowly. “I wanted to help you confront the truth.”
“Truth?” Celebrimbor repeated, his lips twitching into a faint, bitter smile. “And yet you got it wrong. He wouldn’t have spoken like that. He wouldn’t have used those words. You made him too cold. Too cruel. He wasn’t always like that. Even at his worst… he knew me too well.”
The silence that followed was heavy, thick with unspoken tension.
Truth be told, Celebrimbor already knew what they feared. He had known for some time now.
He
should
let go. He
should
heal. He should hate the one who had manipulated, used, and ultimately destroyed him. He should want to forget the lies, the betrayal, the darkness that had consumed him.
He didn’t want to.
“I know who Annatar really is,” Celebrimbor said, his voice barely above a whisper now. “I know what he did to me. But I also know that no other could’ve brought me where he did. I loved him for it. I still do.”
That, more than anything, seemed to silence the Valar. They had heard this before, of course, but it never grew easier for them to understand. To hear Celebrimbor speak of love when the very one he loved had betrayed him so deeply.
But Celebrimbor knew, even Sauron’s lies had threads of truth woven into them.
He had seen the surprise in Annatar’s eyes when he pulled him close in the dream. That had been bittersweetly accurate.
For once, the dream had felt right. The expression, the flicker of genuine feeling behind those golden eyes -
that
was real. That was the Annatar he knew. The one who had adored him, even if it had been twisted by darker motives.
Nienna’s tears had begun to flow again, her sorrow for him endless. Estë stood quietly, her expression unreadable, but there was no disappointment in her gaze - only quiet empathy. Irmo’s face remained thoughtful, though he said nothing for a long while.
I love you,
he had whispered to the illusion in his dream. And it hadn’t felt like a lie.
Now, sitting in the sterile reality of his chamber, the memory of the dream felt more like a gift than anything else. He didn’t care if the Valar thought it a step backward.
After a long pause, Irmo finally spoke again. “It is your choice, Tyelperinquar. But understand this - clinging to what was, to what
you believe
was real, may not bring you the peace you seek.”
Celebrimbor closed his eyes, exhaling slowly. He lay back in the bed, staring up at the ceiling. “I don’t seek peace,” he said softly.
No, he didn’t need peace. All he wanted was the memory of Annatar, of the golden light, of the lies that had felt so achingly real.
Estë’s expression softened, no longer tinged with disappointment, but with something like understanding. Irmo, however, remained quiet, his gaze thoughtful, as if he was weighing Celebrimbor’s words carefully.
Estë finally spoke now. “You still believe that some part of him truly cared for you?” Her voice was soft, almost as if she had begun to understand his feelings.
“I
know
he did,” Celebrimbor replied, his tone unwavering.
